title: The Dow Slipped 40 Points Because Brexit Is Like a Bad BBC Soap Opera
text:
Text size

Falling Back. All three major stock indexes closed in the red on Tuesday. There was good and bad news for supporters of both Brexit and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. U.S. existing-home sales fell in September, while crude oil futures rose following reports that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies might consider further production cuts.

Biogen stock (ticker: BIIB) soared on news that the company plans to seek U.S. regulatory approval for its Alzheimer’s treatment. Facebook stock (FB) is under pressure as state attorneys and legal experts continue to build their antitrust case against the social media giant. Walt Disney stock (DIS) jumped and Netflix stock (NFLX) tumbled after Verizon Communications (VZ) said it will give wireless customers one free year of Disney+. In today’s After the Bell, we...

look at the latest Brexit vote and its implications;

check on global crude prices and OPEC’s plan;

and wonder why existing-home sales fell in September despite low mortgage rates.

Protracted Divorce

Stocks ended the day with small losses, as investors continue watching the development of multiple geopolitical issues and gauge the level of uncertainty. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 39.54 points, or 0.15%, to close at 26,788.10. The S&P 500 has lost 10.73 points, or 0.36%, to finish at 2995.99, and the Nasdaq Composite has fallen 58.69 points, or 0.72%, to close at 8104.30.

The United Kingdom’s divorce from the European Union has been stuck in back-and-forth negotiations since the U.K. voted to leave the bloc in 2016. Less than a week ahead of the Oct. 31 deadline—already extended from Mar. 29—it seems that the Brexit saga may have finally come to an endgame.

On Tuesday, U.K. lawmakers voted to endorse Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s new Brexit deal. However, in a second vote minutes later, lawmakers rejected the three-day timetable proposed by Johnson’s government to push the deal through by the end of the month. Lawmakers said they needed more time to look at the deal and won’t rush to meet the Oct. 31 deadline.

The British government has already requested the EU leaders for a delay to Brexit, but Johnson said he would call an election if the parliament tried to push the ratification beyond the end of the year.

Editor's Choice

As prospects for global growth and oil demand weakens, crude prices have been under pressure despite the supply disruption in some regions. Against that backdrop, OPEC members and allies will reportedly consider making deeper reductions to crude output when they meet in Vienna this December.

On the news, global oil benchmark Brent crude gained 1.26% to $59.70 a barrel on the ICE Futures Europe exchange, while West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.59% to reach $54.16 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Lifted by higher crude prices, energy stocks in the S&P 500 were the best-performing sector within the index, rising 1.3% on Tuesday.

Sales of existing homes dropped 2.2% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 5.38 million from 5.50 million in August. September sales were also lower than the 5.40 million economists were expecting. Despite the monthly decline, sales were 3.9% higher than a year ago.

The September decline in sales doesn’t necessarily mean consumers are less willing to buy houses. After all, mortgage rates have been declining as the Federal Reserve continued to ease its monetary policy. The tight supply in the housing market might be one of the reasons: Inventories were down from last year, while the median sales price increased across all four regions nationwide.
